qas.question: What uses non-spatial memory to memorize spatial information?

context: Memorization is <a1_0><b6_0>a method of learning that allows an individual to recall information verbatim<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <a0_0><b5_0>Rote learning<b5_0/><a0_0/> is the method most often used. Methods of memorizing things have been the subject of much discussion over the years with some writers, such as Cosmos Rossellius <a2_0><b7_0>using visual alphabets<b7_0/>.<a2_0/> The spacing effect <a3_0>shows that an individual is more likely to remember a list of items when rehearsal is spaced over an extended period of time<a3_0/>. In contrast to this is cramming: an intensive memorization in a short period of time. Also relevant is the Zeigarnik effect which <a4_0><b8_0>states that people remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed ones<b8_0/>.<a4_0/> <b9_0>The so-called Method of loci<b9_0/> uses spatial memory to memorize non-spatial information.
